contentrichtext.text: {{About|the New Testament figure|the Christian theologian and philosopher of the 5th–6th century|Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite}} {{Infobox saint |name=Saint Dionysius the Areopagite |birth_date=around 1st century A.C. |death_date=around 1st century A.C. |feast_day=3 October |venerated_in=[[Roman Catholicism]]<br>[[Eastern Orthodoxy]] |image=Menologion of Basil 025.jpg |imagesize=300px |caption=Greek [[icon]] of St. Dionysius |birth_place= |death_place= |titles=[[Hieromartyr]] |beatified_date= |beatified_place= |beatified_by= |canonized_date= |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes=Vested as a [[bishop]], holding a [[Gospel Book]] |patronage= Lawyers |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= |issues= |prayer= |prayer_attrib= }} '''Dionysius the Areopagite''' ([[Greek language|Greek]] ''{{lang|grc|Διονύσιος ὁ Ἀρεοπαγίτης}}'') was a [[judge]] of the [[Areopagus]] who, as related in the ''[[Acts of the Apostles]]'', ({{Bibleverse||Acts|17:34|KJV}}), was converted to [[Christianity]] by the preaching of the [[Paul of Tarsus|Apostle Paul]] during the [[Areopagus sermon]]. According to [[Dionysius of Corinth]], quoted by [[Eusebius of Caesarea|Eusebius]], this Dionysius then became the first [[List of Archbishops of Athens|Bishop of Athens]].<ref>Eusebius, ''[[Church History (Eusebius)|Historia Ecclesiae]]'' III: iv</ref> ==Historic confusions== In the early 6th century, a series of famous writings of a [[mystical]] nature, employing [[Neoplatonic]] language to elucidate Christian theological and mystical ideas, was ascribed to the Areopagite.<ref>[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/pseudo-dionysius-areopagite/ ''Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy''] on the confusion between Dionysius and Pseudo-Dionysius</ref> They have long been recognized as [[pseudepigrapha]] and are now attributed to "[[Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite]]". Dionysius was also popularly misidentified with the martyr of [[Gaul]], Dionysius, the first [[Bishop of Paris]], [[Denis|Saint Denis]]. In the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], Dionysius the Areopagite and Saint Denis of Paris are celebrated as one commemoration on 3 October. == See also == * [[Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite]] * [[St. Dionysus Institute in Paris]] * [[Early centers of Christianity#Greece]] == References == <References/> == Sources == *{{sep entry|pseudo-dionysius-areopagite/#DioPer|Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite|Kevin Corrigan and Michael Harrington}} * Owen Gingerich, ''The Book Nobody Read'', Penguin Books, 2004, pp. 190–191 ==External links== *[http://ocafs.oca.org/FeastSaintsViewer.asp?SID=4&ID=1&FSID=102843 Hieromartyr Dionysius the Areopagite the Bishop of Athens] Orthodox [[icon]] and [[synaxarion]] *[http://www.westsrbdio.org/prolog/my.html?month=October&day=3&Go.x=11&Go.y=11 The Holy Hieromartyr Dionysius the Areopagite] entry from the ''Prologue from Ochrid'' by [[Nikolaj Velimirović]] * [http://www.fairytalechannel.org/2010_04_12_archive.html A Translation of Grimm's Saga No. 439 about Saint Dionysius and King Dagobert] {{New Testament people}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Dionysius The Areopagite | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dionysius The Areopagite}} [[Category:Ancient Athenians]] [[Category:Doctors of the Church]] [[Category:Roman-era Greeks]] [[Category:Eastern Orthodox saints]] [[Category:Hesychasm]] [[Category:1st-century bishops]] [[Category:New Testament people]] [[Category:Ante-Nicene Christian martyrs]] [[Category:Converts to Christianity]] [[Category:Saints of Roman Athens]] [[Category:Book of Acts]]
